reviewText: I bought "BW2" from Amazon, and I recorded "BW1" from cable years ago. These two movies remind me of "Toxic," a take-off on Frankenstein's monster by Golan-Globus. "Toxic" was purposely bad, tongue in cheek, and very good as a result. I don't think that the Italians went down that road on purpose; camp is not a European thing. Maybe they just tried to make a buck on an ultra-violent film.I'm not going to explain unnecessarily the whole movie. Notice how short the credits are. There is one cameraman and an assistant! I enjoyed the droogs, who in their tin suits and face masks are unrecognizable so that they can be killed again and again to save money.There is a wig person, but no Foley artist. I liked Trash's dungarees better than the baggy pants he wore in "BW2." What ever happened to him? What a stud: he must be at least 6'3" like Tom Welling, but with a tiny waist and huge pecs. Was that hair his? He strutted in "BW1," not so much in "BW2." In one scene he has a gun in a holster, in the next he he has none. Then someone gives him a weapon, but in the next scene he has none until he gets a flamethrower! Every teenager should have one.I recommend both; view "BW1" before "BW2." I gave only four stars because it needs more violence; albeit it pushed well beyond the limit for its day. A remake would be a smash hit, but there aren't any stud actors around that I know of. Only Alex Pettyfer comes to mind although he is not a perfect choice.

reviewText: I saw this as a kid in 1983-84 in ny city. It was a hard film to forget, and now going back to see it, even though there are laughs, but this film has a charm to it thats hard to resist if you like films of this sort. It's a "so bad film, it's good" movie, complete with a crazy plot and goon characters that will allow you to just enjoy the entertainent value a film like this has.I won't go into story, as it is also in the other reviews, this is a film, for folks who love italian rip offs and have that b quality to it, then this film will appeal to you.
summary: Great italian exploitation film, that takes two films (The Warriors and Mad Max) combines them to make a comic book action film!

reviewText: This has to be the best action movie ever!  Wall to wall explosions, shootouts, martial arts fighting, and a lot of pyrotechnics.  Enzo G. Castellari also threw in a lot of his usual slow motion which makes the  film quite stylish as well.  Great musical score by the late Francesco De  Masi fits in perfectly with some great scenes.  Favorite scene - Romano  Puppo smashes a baseball bat right through a disinfestor's helmet, captured  in glittering slow motion of course.  Be sure to check out other great  Italian action titles, such as Endgame, The Last Hunter, Thunder Warrior,  1990: The Bronx Warriors, and After the Fall of New York.  They're all  great movies!

reviewText: 1982's "1990: the Bronx Warriors," directed by Enzo G. Castellari, was just one of the many low budget Italian post-apocalyptic adventures to be made in the wake of John Carpenter's seminal "Escape from New York" (not to mention George Miller's first two "Mad Max" epics).  It was a noted success and was naturally followed up but one year later by what I consider to be its even better sequel, "Escape from the Bronx" (1983).The story here concerns a sinister corporation who send in "disinfestation squads," under the command of veteran American actor Henry Silva, to clear out the remaining inhabitants of the Bronx to make way for a proposed super city of the future.  The Bronx in this film consists of dilapidated abandoned buildings occupied by urban dwellers who are burned alive at the hands of the squads' nifty flamethrowers.  The gangs of the area, led by Trash (Mark Gregory), who reprises his role from the original and again has a heavy metal look that could have earned him an audition for Motorhead, fight against the corporation to retain control of their home.What we have here is one intense, high energy action flick.  The disinfestation squads wear cool black helmets and silver uniforms and find and incinerate Trash's parents, leading him on a quest for revenge.  Castellari undoubtedly knows how to make movies like this, and provides non-stop explosions and machine gun duels, all of which are very well-staged, not to mention cool underground urban set pieces that are really neat to look at.And one reason I'm admittedly such a fan of low budget Italian movies of this era is because they always provide a chance to view some really gorgeous Italian women who both look fine and often wield guns and/or swords to boot.  In "2020 Texas Gladiators" it was Sabrina Siani, and here the resident eye candy is played by Moana Pozzi as Juana, who though in a small role looks extremely hot in her tight black leather bodysuit and joins with Trash and his crew at the end to fight against Silva and the flamethrower guys.  Truly choice indeed.This 2005 Australian import DVD on Stomp Entertainment is Region-free and therefore playable on DVD players around the world.  Though it is all but devoid of special features, it at least has a nice to look at anamorphic widescreen transfer, along with cool packaging that thankfully includes the original movie poster for the DVD cover.All in all, for lovers of low budget Italian post-apocalyptic trash from the early '80s, "Escape from the Bronx" is near the top of the heap.  Highly recommended for fans of the genre.
